elements.content: A series of lanthanide organic complexes, namely, [Ln2­PDC3­(H2O)3]­H2O (Ln = Eu, Tb, Eu x ­Tb2–x , H2PDC: pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylic acid), were synthesized via hydrothermal method. Eu-PDC was characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The powder X-ray diffraction, Fourier transform infrared spectra, and thermogravimetric analysis illustrate that Eu-PDC, Tb-PDC, and Eu x ­Tb2–x -PDC complexes are isostructural. All the complexes exhibit strong emission even though water molecules coordinated in the structure. Tunable emission color from green, yellow to red is realized by adjusting the Eu/Tb ratio in mixed Eu x ­Tb2–x -PDC complexes. Energy transfer from Tb3+ to Eu3+ is discussed in detail via fluorescence decay and time resolution spectra. The detailed energy transfer process sees that the emitting color of Eu0.15­Tb1.85-PDC shifts from green to orange in a time interval of 153–790 μs. In addition, temperature-dependent emission of the Eu0.05­Tb1.95-PDC complex indicates that it is a potential solid state material for a luminescence thermometer in the range of 293–333 K. The temperature resolution is less than 0.16 K. The optical properties of the EuTb-PDC complex indicate that it is a multifunctional luminescent material with promising applications in temperature sensing, time resolution imaging, lighting, and displaying.

Eu-PDC was characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. elements.content: The ligand in [Ln2PDC3(H2O)3]­H2O crystals harvests NUV light and transfers energy to the central Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions, which results in strong and tunable emission. The self-reference optical thermometry is realized by the emission intensity ratio of I Tb/I Eu, and the temperature resolution is better than 0.13 K in the physiological range. The emitting color of the mixed-lanthanide complex shifts from green to orange in a time interval of 790 μs.

elements.content: Lanthanide organic complexes are admirable luminescence materials provided with numerous desirable characteristics comprising designable structure, large Stokes shifts, narrow emission bands as well as long luminescence lifetimes and so on. Generally, direct excitation of Ln­(III) ions is not efficient as a result of parity-forbidden intraconfigurational f–f transitions. In order to overcome the shortcoming, suitable organic ligands are selected to coordinate and sensitize the central metal ions, which leads to a great improvement of the emission efficiency of lanthanide cations. The pyridinedicarboxylic acids have been demonstrated to be excellent ligands for lanthanide organic complexes owing to carboxylic groups which can form abundant coordination modes and demonstrate excellent performances. Recently, pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2PDC) as a significant carboxylate ligand has attracted much interest in many fields. These previous reports illustrate that lanthanide organic complexes with linker 3,5-PDC exhibit outstanding thermally stable, optical and magnetic properties. However, the optical properties of the above lanthanide complexes have rarely been profoundly researched and discussed yet, as well as not further expanded to the application fields.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Lanthanide organic complexes are admirable luminescence materials provided with numerous desirable characteristics comprising designable structure, large Stokes shifts, narrow emission bands as well as long luminescence lifetimes and so on. Generally, direct excitation of Ln(III) ions is not efficient as a result of parity-forbidden intraconfigurational f-f transitions. In order to overcome the shortcoming, suitable organic ligands are selected to coordinate and sensitize the central metal ions, which leads to a great improvement of the emission efficiency of lanthanide cations. The pyridinedicarboxylic acids have been demonstrated to be excellent ligands for lanthanide organic complexes owing to carboxylic groups which can form abundant coordination modes and demonstrate excellent performances. Recently, pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2PDC) as a significant carboxylate ligand has attracted much interest in many fields. These previous reports illustrate that lanthanide organic complexes with linker 3,5-PDC exhibit outstanding thermally stable, optical and magnetic properties. However, the optical properties of the above lanthanide complexes have rarely been profoundly researched and discussed yet, as well as not further expanded to the application fields.

elements.content: On the other hand, terbium (Tb) and europium (Eu) mixed-lanthanide organic complexes which have bright red (Eu)/green (Tb) emitting, long lifetime about 1–2 ms, and efficient energy transfer are researched widely. For example, basing on Tb3+ → Eu3+ energy transfer, some Eu/Tb mixed organic complexes achieve tunable emitting color from green finally to red under the irradiation of a UV lamp, which is considered as promising light emitting materials potentially. Meanwhile, the long luminescence lifetime of Eu/Tb organic complexes has also gotten numerous attentions which can apply to time-resolved long-lived luminescence imaging and time-resolved fluoroimmunoassays.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, terbium (Tb) and europium (Eu) mixed-lanthanide organic complexes which have bright red (Eu)/green (Tb) emitting, long lifetime about 1-2 ms, and efficient energy transfer are researched widely. For example, basing on Tb3+ → Eu3+ energy transfer, some Eu/Tb mixed organic complexes achieve tunable emitting color from green finally to red under the irradiation of a UV lamp, which is considered as promising light emitting materials potentially. Meanwhile, the long luminescence lifetime of Eu/Tb organic complexes has also gotten numerous attentions which can apply to time-resolved long-lived luminescence imaging and time-resolved fluoroimmunoassays.

elements.content: Besides another important application of luminescent organic complexes is their purpose as luminescent thermometer and temperature-dependent imaging reagents. The precise measurement of temperature has emerged as a key factor in areas such as nanomedicine, micro-optics, microelectronics, microfluidics, and photonics. Comparing with traditional temperature thermometers, luminescence-based temperature probes draw much attention because of the noncontact, accuracy, and applicability in micro- and nanoscale. Carlos et al. employed 9-fluorenone-2,7-dicarboxylic acid as organic ligand and Eu/Tb as the central metal ions to form luminescent organic complexes, which demonstrated one luminescent thermometer operating in the 12–320 K temperature range. It is worth noting that investigators have already achieved on metal organic complexes as temperature probes in a low temperature range (10–273 K). Nevertheless, the sensitivity still should be enhanced in the physiological temperature range (298–318 K) as well as the thermometer for this temperature range has tempting application prospect in bioscience fields.

elements.content: In this work, a series of lanthanide organic complexes [Ln2­PDC3­(H2O)3]­H2O (Ln = Eu, Tb, Eu x ­Tb2–x ) were synthesized by hydrothermal method based on a pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylic acid linker. PXRD, FTIR, and TGA demonstrate that all of them are isostructural. The excitation and emission spectra reveal Eu-PDC and Tb-PDC have excellent luminescence properties. By adjusting Eu and Tb content percentage, the tunable emission of mixed Eu x ­Tb2–x from green, yellow to red was realized. Energy transfer of Tb3+ → Eu3+ is discussed in detail via fluorescence lifetime and time resolution spectra. Moreover, the study on temperature dependence of Eu0.05­Tb1.95-PDC indicates that this system is a potential solid state material as luminescence thermometer.

PXRD, FTIR, and TGA demonstrate that all of them are isostructural. The excitation and emission spectra reveal Eu-PDC and Tb-PDC have excellent luminescence properties. By adjusting Eu and Tb content percentage, the tunable emission of mixed Eu x Tb2-x  from green, yellow to red was realized. Energy transfer of Tb3+ → Eu3+ is discussed in detail via fluorescence lifetime and time resolution spectra. Moreover, the study on temperature dependence of Eu0.05Tb1.95-PDC indicates that this system is a potential solid state material as luminescence thermometer.

elements.content: The ligand pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2PDC) and rare earth oxide Eu2O3 (99.99%) and Tb4O7 (99.99%) were purchased from J&K Chemical (Beijing) and Aladdin (Shanghai), respectively. The chemicals were used without further purification.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

The ligand pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2PDC) and rare earth oxide Eu2O3 (99.99%) and Tb4O7 (99.99%) were purchased from J&K Chemical (Beijing) and Aladdin (Shanghai), respectively. The chemicals were used without further purification.

elements.content: All lanthanide organic complexes [Ln2­PDC3­(H2O)3]·nH2O (Ln = Tb, Eu, Eu x ­Tb2–x ) were synthesized via a similar process. At first, lanthanide oxide Eu2O3 and/or Tb4O7 were dissolved with diluted nitric acid; then the solution was heated tenderly to dryness. This process was repeated several times until the pH value of the solution was near 7. A mixture of H2PDC, Ln­(NO3)3·nH2O was dissolved in ethanol/H2O (4:1, V/V). Diluted NaOH solution was utilized to regulate the pH value of the solution. After mixing of the reagents, precipitates appeared immediately. The mixture including the precipitates was transferred into a 50 mL stainless steel reactor with a Teflon liner and heated at 160 °C for 24 h and then cooled slowly to room temperature (5 °C/h). Colorless needle-like crystals were harvested by filtration and washed with ethanol and H2O several times. The CHN elemental analysis results are summarized in Table S1.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the Samples

All lanthanide organic complexes [Ln2PDC3(H2O)3]⋅nH2O (Ln = Tb, Eu, Eu x Tb2-x ) were synthesized via a similar process. At first, lanthanide oxide Eu2O3 and/or Tb4O7 were dissolved with diluted nitric acid; then the solution was heated tenderly to dryness. This process was repeated several times until the pH value of the solution was near 7. A mixture of H2PDC, Ln(NO3)3⋅nH2O was dissolved in ethanol/H2O (4:1, V/V). Diluted NaOH solution was utilized to regulate the pH value of the solution. After mixing of the reagents, precipitates appeared immediately. The mixture including the precipitates was transferred into a 50 mL stainless steel reactor with a Teflon liner and heated at 160 °C for 24 h and then cooled slowly to room temperature (5 °C/h). Colorless needle-like crystals were harvested by filtration and washed with ethanol and H2O several times. The CHN elemental analysis results are summarized in Table S1.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data of Eu-PDC were taken on an Oxford Xcalibur (Atlas Gemini ultra) diffractometer with a low-temperature device at 134 K using graphite monochromatic Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation source. Data collection and determination of the unit cell were carried out with Bruker SAINT Program. The structure of Eu-PDC was determined by direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method with the SHELX-97.
elements.clean_text:
Characterization

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data of Eu-PDC were taken on an Oxford Xcalibur (Atlas Gemini ultra) diffractometer with a low-temperature device at 134 K using graphite monochromatic Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation source. Data collection and determination of the unit cell were carried out with Bruker SAINT Program. The structure of Eu-PDC was determined by direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method with the SHELX-97.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) with Cu–Kα (λ = 1.5406 Å) at 36 kV and 20 mA. Data were collected from 2θ = 15–50° at a scanning speed of 2 o/min. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the complexes was performed on the SDT Q650 instrument at a heating rate of 20 °C/min from room temperature to 1200 °C under a N2 atmosphere. Fourier transform infrared spectra (FTIR) were recorded using an Agilent Cary 630 FIRT spectrometer. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were recorded on a Thermo Scientific FLASH 2000. A Cary 5000 UV–vis–NIR spectrophotometer equipped with a Φ130 mm integrating sphere was used to collect diffuse-reflectance spectra. The spectra were recorded at room temperature while barium sulfate acted as the standard. The excitation and emission spectra were measured by an FLS920 fluorescence spectrophotometer equipped with a 450 W xenon lamp as the light source and a Shimadzu R9287 photomultiplier as the detector. The luminescence decay and time resolution spectra of the samples were recorded with the same spectrophotometer with a pulsed xenon lamp as the light source. Supporting software “F900” can measure the time-resolved spectrum after the pulsed light source stop excited. The suitable step size, time range, and wavelength range are carefully optimized to get high-quality spectra. The quantum yields of the solid complexes were measured by an integrating sphere attachment of the spectrometer. The powder samples were mounted in the sample holder, and a Xe lamp was used to excite the samples at 284 nm. Quantum yields were determined by comparing the spectral intensities of the lamp and the sample emission.

elements.content: The crystal structure of the colorless needle-like crystal [Eu2­(PDC)3­(H2O)3]·H2O was investigated by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Crystal data and structure refinement parameters are displayed in . This complex crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Description

The crystal structure of the colorless needle-like crystal [Eu2(PDC)3(H2O)3]⋅H2O was investigated by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Crystal data and structure refinement parameters are displayed in . This complex crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n.

As shown in , the asymmetric unit of Eu-PDC consists of a homodinuclear form; namely, it contains two lanthanide centers europium atoms (Eu1, Eu2). These two metal atoms are bridged by six oxygen atoms (O4, O5, O6, O7, O8, O10) from four carboxylate ligands in diverse coordination modes. Herein, PDC2– is a tetradentate ligand; it connects metal centers using both carboxylate groups of μ:η1-η1 (O8-C14-O7 or O6-C13-O5) coordination modes (Figure S1, Mode-1) or carboxylate groups adopt a μ:η1-η1 (O2-C6-O1) bridging and bridging-chelating coordination mode μ:η2-η1 (O4-C7-O3). One oxygen atom in the carboxylate group connects two metals ions, the other one oxygen atom connects one metal ion, and the carboxylate group coordinates to two metals, as shown in Figure S1 (Mode-2).

elements.content: The selected bond lengths (Å) and bond angles (deg) in Eu-PDC complex are listed in Table S2. The distance between Eu1 and Eu2 centers is 3.8528 Å, which is close to that reported in other europium carboxylate complexes featuring a homodinuclear structure. The similar Eu–Eu distance possibly results from the analogous bridging binding mode. The Eu–O bond lengths are in the range 2.294–2.637 Å, which are in agreement with the reference values reported for the related lanthanide pyridinedicarboxylic complexes. The longest Eu–O bond involves the oxygen atoms of tridentate bridging ligands (Eu1–O3, 2.615 Å; Eu2–O9, 2.637 Å). The shortest Eu–O bond is associated with the bidentate bridging ligand (Eu1–O1, 2.294 Å; Eu2–O7, 2.329 Å). Besides the bond lengths of Eu atoms and the oxygen atoms from coordinated H2O reveal that Eu2–O (Eu2–O11, 2.500 Å; Eu2–O12, 2.408 Å) is longer than Eu1–O (Eu1–O13, 2.380 Å).
elements.clean_text: The selected bond lengths (Å) and bond angles (deg) in Eu-PDC complex are listed in Table S2. The distance between Eu1 and Eu2 centers is 3.8528 Å, which is close to that reported in other europium carboxylate complexes featuring a homodinuclear structure. The similar Eu-Eu distance possibly results from the analogous bridging binding mode. The Eu-O bond lengths are in the range 2.294-2.637 Å, which are in agreement with the reference values reported for the related lanthanide pyridinedicarboxylic complexes. The longest Eu-O bond involves the oxygen atoms of tridentate bridging ligands (Eu1-O3, 2.615 Å; Eu2-O9, 2.637 Å). The shortest Eu-O bond is associated with the bidentate bridging ligand (Eu1-O1, 2.294 Å; Eu2-O7, 2.329 Å). Besides the bond lengths of Eu atoms and the oxygen atoms from coordinated H2O reveal that Eu2-O (Eu2-O11, 2.500 Å; Eu2-O12, 2.408 Å) is longer than Eu1-O (Eu1-O13, 2.380 Å).

elements.content: It is worth noting that there are two crystalline unequal Eu sites in this complex, which is different from the reported literatures. Eu1 is eight-coordinated by seven carboxyl oxygen atoms and one oxygen atom of coordinated H2O. Eu2 is nine-coordinated by seven carboxyl oxygen atoms and two oxygen atoms of coordinated H2O. The coordination polyhedron around Eu1 can be described as a distorted trigonal dodecahedron, while Eu2 sits in the distorted tricapped trigonal prism geometry (b). The O–Eu–O bonds angles in the coordination polyhedron range from 50.3° to 156.8° as listed in Table S3. It depends on the bridging binding mode. The two oxygen atoms which belong to the μ:η2-η1 bridging mode constituted the least O–Eu–O bond angle with Eu atom (O3–Eu1–O4, 50.7°). The carboxylic oxygen atoms of two ligands with different bridging modes formed the largest O–Eu–O bond angle with Eu atoms (O1–Eu1–O4, 156.8°). Owing to the bidentate and tridentate binding type, the carboxylate group is rather asymmetric. Indeed, the C–O distances for bidentate bridging carboxylate groups are longer than tridentate bridging carboxylate groups. The O–C–O angle range for the different carboxylate groups varies from 120.6° to 126.1°, which can be attributed to different coordination modes. The largest O–C–O bond angle is derived from the carboxylate group of PDC2– ligand binding with Eu atom via μ:η1-η1 mode (O11–C21–012, 126.1°).

Indeed, the C-O distances for bidentate bridging carboxylate groups are longer than tridentate bridging carboxylate groups. The O-C-O angle range for the different carboxylate groups varies from 120.6° to 126.1°, which can be attributed to different coordination modes. The largest O-C-O bond angle is derived from the carboxylate group of PDC2- ligand binding with Eu atom via μ:η1-η1 mode (O11-C21-012, 126.1°).

elements.content: The crystal packing view along the c axis clearly shows two carboxylic groups of the PDC2– ligand link three asymmetric binuclear units through Mode-2 (Figure S2a), and Mode-1 contact with two binuclear units along the b axis (Figure S2b). As exhibited in a, the neighboring binuclear units are linked to each other by ligands to form a chain structure along the same direction, and the noncoordinated water molecules are located in the void. Similarly, two adjacent chains linked by Mode-1 further extend to b and c directions, forming a layer structure (b). Different layers accumulate along the c direction, forming a three-dimensional structure by Mode-2 of PDC2– (c). The uncoordinated water molecules are occupied between layers. The lattice water molecules are located between different layer structures. Inter- and intramolecular hydrogen bonds are formed (Table S4) with hydrogen atoms in water molecules as proton donor and oxygen atoms in water molecules (O13, O14, O15, O16) as well as nitrogen atoms along with carboxylate oxygen atoms as proton acceptors.

elements.content: The infrared spectra of Ln-PDC complexes and H2PDC ligand are exhibited in Figure S3. The sharp peak located at 3094 cm–1 corresponds to the stretching vibrations ν­(OH) of the carboxylate group. This peak is weaken or almost disappeared in the complexes. The other peaks are derived from the vibration of carboxylate groups (1700–1300 cm–1) and pyridine rings (1200–850 cm–1). It is well-known that the difference Δν between the asymmetric stretching vibration and symmetric one (Δν = νas – νsym) of the carboxylate group depends on its coordination mode. The split bands (1545, 1611 cm–1) are assigned to asymmetric stretching vibrations νasym(COO–). The very intense peak at 1370 cm–1 originates from the symmetric stretching vibrations νsym(COO–). The Δν values (241 and 175 cm–1) are close to the value expected for a bidentate coordination mode. The absence of the characteristic bands at around 1700 cm–1 indicated the complete deprotonation of the PDC2– ligand in the complexes. The weak broad band at 3450, 3599 cm–1 formed by the stretching vibrations of −OH bonds from the hydrogen bond of water molecules which illustrates the mono-crystal structure of Eu-PDC contains water molecules. The similarity in FTIR spectra of Eu-PDC, Tb-PDC, and Eu0.05­Tb1.95-PDC illustrates that the functional groups and local environments in these complexes are analogous. The PXRD results with identical diffraction patterns for all the complexes (Figure S4) also illustrate that the synthesized samples are isostructural.
elements.clean_text:
FTIR Results and Analysis

The infrared spectra of Ln-PDC complexes and H2PDC ligand are exhibited in Figure S3. The sharp peak located at 3094 cm-1 corresponds to the stretching vibrations ν(OH) of the carboxylate group. This peak is weaken or almost disappeared in the complexes. The other peaks are derived from the vibration of carboxylate groups (1700-1300 cm-1) and pyridine rings (1200-850 cm-1). It is well-known that the difference Δν between the asymmetric stretching vibration and symmetric one (Δν = νas - νsym) of the carboxylate group depends on its coordination mode. The split bands (1545, 1611 cm-1) are assigned to asymmetric stretching vibrations νasym(COO-). The very intense peak at 1370 cm-1 originates from the symmetric stretching vibrations νsym(COO-). The Δν values (241 and 175 cm-1) are close to the value expected for a bidentate coordination mode. The absence of the characteristic bands at around 1700 cm-1 indicated the complete deprotonation of the PDC2- ligand in the complexes. The weak broad band at 3450, 3599 cm-1 formed by the stretching vibrations of -OH bonds from the hydrogen bond of water molecules which illustrates the mono-crystal structure of Eu-PDC contains water molecules. The similarity in FTIR spectra of Eu-PDC, Tb-PDC, and Eu0.05Tb1.95-PDC illustrates that the functional groups and local environments in these complexes are analogous. The PXRD results with identical diffraction patterns for all the complexes (Figure S4) also illustrate that the synthesized samples are isostructural.

elements.content: Thermal gravimetric analyses of Eu-PDC, Tb-PDC, and Eu0.05­Tb1.95-PDC were performed in the temperature range of 20–1200 °C. As can be seen from Figure S5, there are two stages in the water-losing process. The previous stage corresponds to three coordination water molecules losing in the crystal of Ln-PDC. The latter one stage hints one uncoordinated water molecule is lost. Subsequently, the complexes begin to decompose. The TGA results show these complexes have enough thermal stability to be utilized in the temperature range of 298–398 K.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analyses (TGA)

Thermal gravimetric analyses of Eu-PDC, Tb-PDC, and Eu0.05Tb1.95-PDC were performed in the temperature range of 20-1200 °C. As can be seen from Figure S5, there are two stages in the water-losing process. The previous stage corresponds to three coordination water molecules losing in the crystal of Ln-PDC. The latter one stage hints one uncoordinated water molecule is lost. Subsequently, the complexes begin to decompose. The TGA results show these complexes have enough thermal stability to be utilized in the temperature range of 298-398 K.

elements.content: The UV–vis diffuse-reflectance spectra of the ligand and complexes are depicted in Figure S6a; the strong broad band in the UV range, which appears in every sample, is attributed to the absorption of the organic ligand. It is ascribed to an overlap of the electronic transitions π → π* and n → π* of the organic linker, as the spectrum fitting shows in Figure S6b. Besides the intense wide band, some sharp and weak peaks in the region 310–800 nm originated from the intraconfigurational f → f transitions of Eu3+ and/or Tb3+ ions are also observed in the complexes.
elements.clean_text:
UV-vis Diffuse Reflectance Spectra

The UV-vis diffuse-reflectance spectra of the ligand and complexes are depicted in Figure S6a; the strong broad band in the UV range, which appears in every sample, is attributed to the absorption of the organic ligand. It is ascribed to an overlap of the electronic transitions π → π* and n → π* of the organic linker, as the spectrum fitting shows in Figure S6b. Besides the intense wide band, some sharp and weak peaks in the region 310-800 nm originated from the intraconfigurational f → f transitions of Eu3+ and/or Tb3+ ions are also observed in the complexes.

elements.content: The excitation spectra of Ln-PDC complexes are recorded by monitoring the transition of Tb3+: 5D4 → 7F5 (542 nm) or Eu3+: 5D0 → 7F2 (611 nm). One broad band in the range 230–300 nm is observed. It is attributed to the absorption of the ligand, which indicates the presence of an efficient energy transfer from ligands to metal ions. Moreover, a series of sharp lines are assigned to 7F6 → (5G3/5D2, 5L10, 5D3, 5D4) transitions of Tb3+ (a) and 7F0 → (5H6, 5D4, 5G6, 5L7, 5L6, 5D2) transitions of Eu3+ (b). Under ligand-mediated excitation (λex = 284 nm), Tb-PDC and Eu-PDC present intense emission of corresponding Ln3+ ions in the visible region. Meanwhile, in the emission spectra of Ln-PDC, the transitions of Tb3+: 5D4 → 7F(3‑6) and Eu3+: 5D0 → 7F(0‑2,4) are observed. Even though there are two crystalline unequal Eu sites in the Eu-PDC complex, the splitting of 5D0 → 7F0 is not observed in b. The possible reason might be the resolution of the spectrometer is not high enough and/or the two sites do not lead to a big energy difference. In addition, the fluorescence lifetime and quantum yields are 0.97 ms and 24% for Tb-PDC, 0.45 ms and 16% for Eu-PDC, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

The excitation spectra of Ln-PDC complexes are recorded by monitoring the transition of Tb3+: 5D4 → 7F5 (542 nm) or Eu3+: 5D0 → 7F2 (611 nm). One broad band in the range 230-300 nm is observed. It is attributed to the absorption of the ligand, which indicates the presence of an efficient energy transfer from ligands to metal ions. Moreover, a series of sharp lines are assigned to 7F6 → (5G3/5D2, 5L10, 5D3, 5D4) transitions of Tb3+ (a) and 7F0 → (5H6, 5D4, 5G6, 5L7, 5L6, 5D2) transitions of Eu3+ (b). Under ligand-mediated excitation (λex = 284 nm), Tb-PDC and Eu-PDC present intense emission of corresponding Ln3+ ions in the visible region. Meanwhile, in the emission spectra of Ln-PDC, the transitions of Tb3+: 5D4 → 7F(3-6) and Eu3+: 5D0 → 7F(0-2,4) are observed. Even though there are two crystalline unequal Eu sites in the Eu-PDC complex, the splitting of 5D0 → 7F0 is not observed in b. The possible reason might be the resolution of the spectrometer is not high enough and/or the two sites do not lead to a big energy difference. In addition, the fluorescence lifetime and quantum yields are 0.97 ms and 24% for Tb-PDC, 0.45 ms and 16% for Eu-PDC, respectively.

elements.content: It is illustrated that the coordination complexes Tb-PDC and Eu-PDC emit bright light in the green and red areas. While, the tunable emission colors could be generated from green to red by means of regulating the Eu/Tb ratio in the EuTb-PDC mixed complexes. As shown in a, Ln-PDC shows various emitting colors including green, yellow, orange, and red with the change of Eu/Tb ratio. The CIE chromaticity diagram of Ln-PDC is depicted in b, and insets are photographs of the corresponding Ln-PDC powder under the irradiation of an ultraviolet lamp. The tunable emission color of EuTb-PDC mixed complexes leads to its potential applications in the fields of lighting and displaying.

elements.content: Energy transfer is an extraordinary phenomenon for the luminescence of optical materials. It also plays critical roles in various applications, such as optical thermometers, imaging, energy conversion, time-resolved fluoroimmunoassays, and so on. In the mixed Ln-PDC complexes, there are two energy transfer avenues, which are proved by the excitation and emission spectra of Eu0.05­Tb1.95-PDC as shown in a. Under the excitation at 284 nm, sharp peaks appearing in the emission spectrum are attributed to the characteristic transitions of Tb3+ and Eu3+. This result verifies that energy transfer occurs between the organic ligand and metal ions, and PDC2– is an excellent antenna chromophore to sensitize lanthanide ions (Eu3+, Tb3+). At the same time, through monitoring 611 nm (Eu3+: 5D → 7F2), the feature peaks of Tb3+ are observed in the excitation spectrum of EuTb-PDC, which are noted in the a. Apparently, it verifies the other energy transfer pathway from Tb3+ to Eu3+.

elements.content: The schematic energy transfer process involved in this system is shown in b. Electrons absorb energy from the external light source and transfer from ground state (π) S0 to the excited level (π*) S1 of the organic ligand. From the emission and excitation spectra of H2PDC and Gd-PDC (Figure S7), the singlet and triplet state levels of the ligand are estimated at 285 nm (35 088 cm–1) and 420 nm (23 809 cm–1), respectively. Then energy is transferred from S1 to T1 state via intersystem crossing. The nearby excited states of Tb3+: 5D4 at 20 545 cm–1 are pumped by energy transfer from the triplet state of the ligand. Because Tb3+: 5D4 is higher than Eu3+: 5D0 (17 286 cm–1), partial energy of Tb3+ is further transferred to Eu3+. It effectively enhances Eu3+ emission and depresses Tb3+ emission at the same time. Ultimately, Tb3+ and Eu3+ luminescence centers emit their own unique fluorescence by radiation transitions, and tunable emission colors are realized in the mixed Eu x ­Tb2–x -PDC complexes.

elements.content: In order to deep-going research the energy transfer in the complexes, the lifetime decay curves are recorded by monitoring the 5D4 excited state (542 nm) of Tb3+ ion, shown in a. The fluorescence lifetime variously declines with the increase of Eu3+ percentage. The lifetime values are listed in the figure. In theory, the efficiency of energy transfer from the Tb3+ to Eu3+ follows the formula ηET = 1 – τ/τ0, where τ0 and τ are the luminescence lifetimes of 5D4 excited state of Tb3+ at 542 nm in Tb-PDC and Eu x ­Tb2–x -PDC. For Eu0.15­Tb1.85-PDC, the value of ηET is 86.60%, which illustrates Tb3+ is an outstanding sensitizer in this mixed complex.

elements.content: The time resolution spectra of Eu0.15­Tb1.85-PDC were surveyed by exciting at 484 nm and monitoring at 542 nm. As shown in b, the luminescence intensity of Tb3+ at 542 nm is greater than that of Eu3+ in the first 300 μs. The emitting color of this compound Eu0.15­Tb1.85-PDC exhibits bright green. However, the green emission due to Tb3+ 5D4 → 7F5 transition at 542 nm decreases quickly with time, but that of Eu3+ is enhancing, which corresponds to the energy transfer from Tb3+ to Eu3+ ions. After 300 μs, the luminescence of Tb3+ and Eu3+ both decrease with time. Ultimately, the intensity of Tb3+ is weaker than Eu3+. The time-resolved spectra clearly show the energy transfer from Tb3+ to Eu3+. The corresponding CIE chromaticity diagram of Eu0.15­Tb1.85-PDC derived by the time resolution spectra is presented in c, from which it is seen that the emitting color of this sample shifts from green to orange during the time interval of 790 μs. This might lead to the potential application of time resolution imaging.

elements.content: The mixed Eu x ­Tb2–x -PDC complexes have outstanding photoluminescence performance, which might lead to positive response with the change of temperature. Furthermore, the ratiometric luminescence thermometer based on double luminous centers is a preferred method for temperature sensing. As shown in Figure S8, luminescence intensities of Eu-PDC and Tb-PDC both decrease with increase of temperature in the range of 298–323 K, while the decline of Tb-PDC is more obvious when compared with Eu-PDC. The different temperature response of Eu3+ and Tb3+ may result in excellent ratiometric temperature sensing in the mixed EuTb-PDC complexes. Taking Eu0.05­Tb1.95-PDC as an example, the temperature-dependent emission spectra are demonstrated in the a. With the increase of T, Tb3+, and Eu3+ ions, response to heating is fluorescent quenching, but the extents are distinctive. Therefore, the self-calibrated ratiometric parameter fluorescence intensity ratio (FIR) can be defined by the intensity ratio of Tb3+: 5D4 → 7F5 (542 nm) and Eu3+: 5D0 → 7F2 (611 nm) transitions. In the range of 293–333 K, the experimental data of FIR are shown in b, and the blue solid line is the fitting curve, which follows an empirical function expressed as FIR = A exp ( T 24 ) + B where A = −3.02 × 10–7 and B = 1.29, with a correlation coefficient R 2 = 0.997, indicating that Eu0.05­Tb1.95-PDC is an excellent luminescent thermometer at this temperature range. To appraise the performance of the luminescent thermometers, the absolute and relative sensitivity (SA, SR) are illustrated in a. The sensitivity of Eu0.05­Tb1.95-PDC increases gradually from 293 to 333 K, and gets the maximum values of SA = 1.33% K–1 and SR = 1.37% K–1 at 333 K. In the physiological temperature range (298–318 K), the summit SR is 0.64% K–1 at 318 K.

Ratiometric Temperature Sensing

The mixed Eu x Tb2-x -PDC complexes have outstanding photoluminescence performance, which might lead to positive response with the change of temperature. Furthermore, the ratiometric luminescence thermometer based on double luminous centers is a preferred method for temperature sensing. As shown in Figure S8, luminescence intensities of Eu-PDC and Tb-PDC both decrease with increase of temperature in the range of 298-323 K, while the decline of Tb-PDC is more obvious when compared with Eu-PDC. The different temperature response of Eu3+ and Tb3+ may result in excellent ratiometric temperature sensing in the mixed EuTb-PDC complexes. Taking Eu0.05Tb1.95-PDC as an example, the temperature-dependent emission spectra are demonstrated in the a. With the increase of T, Tb3+, and Eu3+ ions, response to heating is fluorescent quenching, but the extents are distinctive. Therefore, the self-calibrated ratiometric parameter fluorescence intensity ratio (FIR) can be defined by the intensity ratio of Tb3+: 5D4 → 7F5 (542 nm) and Eu3+: 5D0 → 7F2 (611 nm) transitions. In the range of 293-333 K, the experimental data of FIR are shown in b, and the blue solid line is the fitting curve, which follows an empirical function expressed as 1    FIR = A  exp   (   T   24   )  + B   where A = -3.02 × 10-7 and B = 1.29, with a correlation coefficient R 2 = 0.997, indicating that Eu0.05Tb1.95-PDC is an excellent luminescent thermometer at this temperature range. To appraise the performance of the luminescent thermometers, the absolute and relative sensitivity (SA, SR) are illustrated in a. The sensitivity of Eu0.05Tb1.95-PDC increases gradually from 293 to 333 K, and gets the maximum values of SA = 1.33% K-1 and SR = 1.37% K-1 at 333 K. In the physiological temperature range (298-318 K), the summit SR is 0.64% K-1 at 318 K.

elements.content: Besides the sensitivity, a crucial parameter to estimate the function of thermometer material is the temperature resolution δT. It depends on the actual temperature resolvable by the sensing material, and the experimental detection setup. It could be expressed by the following equation δ T = 1 SR δ Δ Δ where δΔ/Δ is the relative error in the determination of the thermometric parameter. The signal-to-noise ratio S/N of the fluorescence spectrometer is 6000:1, which results in a δΔ/Δ of 0.033%. The derived δT curve of the Eu0.05­Tb1.95-PDC thermometer in 293–333 K is shown in b. It demonstrates that δT in this work is better than 0.16 K over the studied temperature range (298–318 K). If the temperature difference of subcellular is 1 K, this Eu0.05­Tb1.95-PDC is precise enough for potential use in biological applications. In addition, the repeatability of the Eu0.05­Tb1.95-PDC thermometer is checked by recording the luminescent response under thermal cycling (c). The intensity ratios almost do not change during the multiple-run test, which indicates good repeatability of these mixed-lanthanide complexes.

elements.content: In summary, a series of Eu/Tb mixed organic complexes with high efficiency luminescence and long fluorescence lifetime have been successfully synthesized under solvothermal conditions. The crystal structure of Eu-PDC is confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Tb-PDC and mixed EuTb-PDC are isomorphic with Eu-PDC which are demonstrated by PXRD, TGA, and FTIR. The emission of the complexes illustrates that the H2PDC is a suitable organic ligand which can serve as “antenna” chromophores to improve the emission efficiency of lanthanide cation. The emitting color of TbEu-PDC luminescent organic complexes can be tuned in a wide color range of green-yellow-red by adjusting the percentage of Eu and Tb content under the excitation at 284 nm single-wavelength ultraviolet light. Fluorescence lifetime and time resolution spectra clearly exhibit Tb3+ → Eu3+ energy transfer. In addition, Eu0.05­Tb1.95-PDC as a self-calibrated luminescent thermometer in the temperature range of 293–333 K is evaluated, with the maximum values of 1.33% K–1 (SA) and 1.37% K–1 (SR) at 333 K. The temperature uncertainty is better than 0.16 K, and thermal cycling indicates the excellent repeatability. On the basis of the above excellent and unique optical properties of the Ln-PDC system, it could be a multifunctional luminescent material with promising applications in temperature sensing, time resolution imaging, lighting, and display.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a series of Eu/Tb mixed organic complexes with high efficiency luminescence and long fluorescence lifetime have been successfully synthesized under solvothermal conditions. The crystal structure of Eu-PDC is confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Tb-PDC and mixed EuTb-PDC are isomorphic with Eu-PDC which are demonstrated by PXRD, TGA, and FTIR. The emission of the complexes illustrates that the H2PDC is a suitable organic ligand which can serve as "antenna" chromophores to improve the emission efficiency of lanthanide cation. The emitting color of TbEu-PDC luminescent organic complexes can be tuned in a wide color range of green-yellow-red by adjusting the percentage of Eu and Tb content under the excitation at 284 nm single-wavelength ultraviolet light. Fluorescence lifetime and time resolution spectra clearly exhibit Tb3+ → Eu3+ energy transfer. In addition, Eu0.05Tb1.95-PDC as a self-calibrated luminescent thermometer in the temperature range of 293-333 K is evaluated, with the maximum values of 1.33% K-1 (SA) and 1.37% K-1 (SR) at 333 K. The temperature uncertainty is better than 0.16 K, and thermal cycling indicates the excellent repeatability. On the basis of the above excellent and unique optical properties of the Ln-PDC system, it could be a multifunctional luminescent material with promising applications in temperature sensing, time resolution imaging, lighting, and display.

cln_elements.content: Thermal gravimetric analyses of Eu-PDC, Tb-PDC, and Eu0.05­Tb1.95-PDC were performed in the temperature range of 20–1200 °C. As can be seen from Figure S5, there are two stages in the water-losing process. The previous stage corresponds to three coordination water molecules losing in the crystal of Ln-PDC. The latter one stage hints one uncoordinated water molecule is lost. Subsequently, the complexes begin to decompose. The TGA results show these complexes have enough thermal stability to be utilized in the temperature range of 298–398 K.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analyses (TGA)

Thermal gravimetric analyses of Eu-PDC, Tb-PDC, and Eu0.05Tb1.95-PDC were performed in the temperature range of 20-1200 °C. As can be seen from Figure S5, there are two stages in the water-losing process. The previous stage corresponds to three coordination water molecules losing in the crystal of Ln-PDC. The latter one stage hints one uncoordinated water molecule is lost. Subsequently, the complexes begin to decompose. The TGA results show these complexes have enough thermal stability to be utilized in the temperature range of 298-398 K.
